title: Britons are happier and less anxious despite the Brexit crisis
text:
The age of Brexit and general uncertainty has not stopped most of the country from getting happier, a survey has found.

Only Northern Ireland, which is in the middle of rows over abortion and gay rights, Brexit and political stalemate – saw higher anxiety, an Office for National Statistics questionnaire showed.

In the year to March, happiness ratings across the UK went up from 7.52 out of 10 to 7.56.

The UK's average anxiety level has fallen since the first records in December 2012

The ONS has produced a national happiness index every year since 2013

And since the first happiness scores were calculated in 2013, life satisfaction has gone up by 3.4 per cent across the country and in London by 4.6 per cent.

Meanwhile, anxiety levels have fallen nationwide by 5.3 per cent and by almost 10 per cent in the North West. However, the ONS offered no explanation for the sunny ratings – although economic factors such as record low unemployment levels may have played a part.

Different ratings in different areas may be connected to pollution, health and the environment, the ONS said.

But in Northern Ireland, happiness levels fell from 7.8 to 7.69 in the year to the end of March. And its anxiety ratings went up from 2.53 out of 10 to 2.83.

The ONS said London ‘continued to report some of the lowest average life satisfaction in the UK’.

Among areas with the highest wellbeing ratings were countryside districts including Ribble Valley, North Devon and cathedral cities such as Winchester.

Yet, despite the ongoing political crisis, Britons - apart from those in Northern Ireland - have felt more optimistic about the future
description: In the year to March, anxiety ratings (left) fell as happiness leapt across the UK. And since the first happiness scores were calculated in 2013, life satisfaction has gone up by 3.4 per cent.
authors: Home Affairs Correspondent For The Daily Mail
